body.p: Mary Russell Mitford's Rienzi, A Tragedy, in Five Acts was first produced at the Theatre Royal, Drury Lane, on October 9, 1828 and was printed in London the same year. The first printed edition of the play appears in the John Cumberland series Cumberland's British Theatre. The London edition by Cumberland went through at least three printings, and Mitford wrote in her Preface to the second: In offering to the world a second edition of [my] Tragedy (the first impression of which was sold in three days), the Authoress has only to repeat her thanks to the excellent performers to whom she was originally indebted for success; and to acknowledge, with sincere gratitude, the almost unanimous kindness with which Rienzi, whether as an acted drama, or a published poem, has been received by the press. Three separate American editions all appeared in 1829: a Baltimore edition published by J. Robinson; a Boston edition published by the Press of the Boston Daily Advertiser; and a New York edition published by Elton and Perkins. The play was collected in 1841 by Philadelphia publisher James Crissy in The Works of Mary Russell Mitford: Prose and Verse. The play was also included an authorized collection, The Dramatic Works of Mary Russell Mitford in 1854 by London publisher Hurst and Blackett.

Rienzi also appeared in drama reprint series' throughout the nineteenth century. In 1837, Behr produced an edition in Berlin. The New York theatrical publisher Samuel French and its London affiliate T. H. Lacy published editions between the 1850s and the 1870s. Wheat and Cornett of New York published an edition in 1879. An excerpt from the play (often titled "Rienzi's Address to the Romans") was also included in several McGuffey's Readers and other school readers, particularly as a text used to teach rhetoric and elocution. The earliest of these is a Boston rhetoric textbook by William Bentley Fowle entitled The New Speaker, Or Exercises in Rhetoric: Being a Selection of Speeches, Dialogues, and Poetry, from the Most Approved American and British Authors, Suitable for Declamation; one of the latest, McGuffey's Sixth Eclectic Reader of 1921; the piece came to be a standard of school-boy recitation.
